title: A Polynomial All Outcome Determinization for Probabilistic Planning

author: Thomas Keller, Department of Computer Science, University of Freiburg

segmentation: I will be talking about polynomial outcomes determinization for probabilistic planning, which is joint work with public.
Elvis.
And let me give you a short outline.
I will first tell you what I understand under probabilistic planning.
For this talk.

After that I will talk about our idea which is called FF based, determinization and finally I will evaluate it.
So for this talk, a probabilistic planning task is a four tuple containing a set of finite domain state variables.
Each with an assigned domain.
We have an initial state which is an assignment of all those variables to a value in the domain.
We have a goal formula that is supposed to be fulfilled in the goal state.
And we have a set of probabilistic operators which consists of a precondition and effect and a cost where the cost is not important for this talk.
And the most important thing, because that is where the probability comes from, is the effect so.
So.
Effects consists of any combination of an empty effect where just nothing happens.
We have atomic effects where a variable V is assigned a value from its domain.
We have conjunctive conjunctive effects that all happen.
We have conditional effects that just happen if the condition C is fulfilled in this state where reaction is applied.
And finally, we have probabilistic effects which take place with some given probability and effects where we have no probabilistic effects and then are called deterministic effects.
OK so I will use an example for this talk which is the Canadian travelers problem CTP which is path planning problem under imperfect information.

And in order to avoid this, our idea was to not multiply all the effects that are there, but simply split the operators and then sequentially apply each of the probabilistic statements one after another.
